sn6.9:1.2: Now at that time the mendicant Kokālika was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn6.9:1.3: Then, late at night, the glorious independent divinity Tudu, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the mendicant Kokālika, and standing in the air he said to him,
sn6.9:1.4: “Kokālika, have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,
sn6.9:1.8: “Didn’t the Buddha declare you a non-returner? So what then are you doing back here?
sn6.9:1.9: See how far you have strayed!”
sn6.9:2.2: with an axe in his mouth.
sn6.9:2.3: A fool cuts themselves with it
sn6.9:3.1: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,
sn6.9:3.2: or criticize someone worthy of praise,
sn6.9:3.3: you choose a losing hand with your own mouth:
sn6.9:3.4: you’ll never find happiness that way.
sn6.9:4.1: A losing hand at dice is a trivial thing,
sn6.9:4.2: if all you lose is your money
sn6.9:4.3: and all you own, even yourself.
sn6.9:4.5: is to hate the holy ones.
sn6.9:5.1: For a hundred thousand times a hundred million,
sn6.9:5.2: times five hundred and thirty-six times <j>a thousand times ten million years
sn6.9:5.3: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,
sn6.9:5.4: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.”
